javadoc:
The RegisterTree class builds and represents relationships between registers. Any
 register that "breaks down" into smaller registers can be represent by a 
 RegisterTree.  The largest register will be at the root and the registers that
 make it up will be its children trees.  The children are RegisterTrees as well
 and can have children trees of thier own.  The root of a RegisterTree may not
 have an associated Register which means that its children are unrelated.  This
 way all the registers of a processor can be represented as a single RegisterTree.

methods.name: <init>
methods.comment: Constructs a RegisterTree with the given name and set of registers

params.name: regs
params.comment: the array of registers to form into a tree

methods.name: <init>
methods.comment: Constructs a RegisterTree with one RegisterTree child

methods.javadoc: Returns the name of this register tree.
methods.name: getName
methods.comment: Returns the name of this register tree.

methods.javadoc:
Adds a Register Tree to this tree.
@param tree the register tree to add
methods.name: add
methods.comment: Adds a Register Tree to this tree.

methods.javadoc:
Get the RegisterTrees that are the children of this RegisterTree
@return a array of RegisterTrees
methods.name: getComponents
methods.comment: Get the RegisterTrees that are the children of this RegisterTree

methods.javadoc:
Returns the Register associated with this tree. This may be null which
 indicates the children RegisterTrees are unrelated to each other.
methods.name: getRegister
methods.comment:
Returns the Register associated with this tree. This may be null which
 indicates the children RegisterTrees are unrelated to each other.

methods.name: getParentRegisterPath
methods.comment:
The parent path of this RegisterTree if it exists or null if this tree has no parent or
 no parent with a register.

return.comment: The parent path of this RegisterTree.

methods.name: getRegisterPath
methods.comment:
The path of this register, which includes the parent path of this RegisterTree if this
 RegisterTree has a parent.

methods.name: getRegisterTree
methods.comment: Returns the RegisterTree for the given register if one exists in this RegisterTree object.

params.name: register1
params.comment: The register for which to get a RegisterTree.

return.comment: The RegisterTree for the given register if one exists in this RegisterTree object.

methods.javadoc:
Removes the register from the children
@param reg the register to remove.
methods.name: remove
methods.comment: Removes the register from the children

name: RegisterTree
comment:
The RegisterTree class builds and represents relationships between registers. Any
 register that "breaks down" into smaller registers can be represent by a 
 RegisterTree.  The largest register will be at the root and the registers that
 make it up will be its children trees.  The children are RegisterTrees as well
 and can have children trees of thier own.  The root of a RegisterTree may not
 have an associated Register which means that its children are unrelated.  This
 way all the registers of a processor can be represented as a single RegisterTree.
